description: From Latin ēmancipātus, past participle of ēmancipō (“to declare (a son) free and independent of the father's power by the thrice-repeated act of mancipātiō and manumissiō, give from one's own power or authority into that of another, give up, surrender”), from ē (“out”) + mancipō (“to transfer ownership in”), from manceps (“purchaser, a contractor, literally, one who takes in hand”), from manus (“hand”) + capiō (“to take”). See manual, and capable.

adjectives.description: emancipate (comparative more emancipate, superlative most emancipate)

verbs.description: emancipate (third-person singular simple present emancipates, present participle emancipating, simple past and past participle emancipated)

definitionGroups.group: To set free from the power of another; to liberate; as:

entries.meaning: To set free, as a minor from a parent
examples: The child was emancipated from its parents

entries.meaning: To set free from slavery or bondage; to give freedom to; to manumit
To free from any controlling influence, especially from anything which exerts undue or evil influence
examples: emancipate someone from prejudices or error
